title.narrative: Supporting Social Dialogue in Emerging Garment Producers

description.narrative: In our textile programme we improve social dialogue in the emerging garment producing countries Ethiopia and Myanmar. We facilitated an international exchange between CETU and CTUM, the confederations of trade unions from Ethiopia and Myanmar respectively, on good practices and mechanisms to promote improvements in social dialog. There was a strong interest from both parties in discussing grievance mechanisms and worker-management dialogue, as well as their experience in advocating for labor law reforms. Union representatives of both confederations were trained in communications and managerial/leadership skills, and CETU was also supported in advocacy skills among female workers representatives. These capacities appeared to bear significant fruits; CETU and their affiliates implemented an advocacy strategy to submit recommendations for amendment to maternity leave allowance and maximum probation periods. Both recommendations were accepted by the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (MOLSA). Solidaridad supported CETU in reviewing and advising on their formal paper of recommendations, and we worked with them to use information from our “Better Mills Initiative” (BMI) program to develop recommendations. The acceptance of the recommendations by MOLSA to extend the period of maternity leave for female workers from 90 to 120 days is particularly pleasing, and represents a significant achievement in a context where the Government remains at times apparently highly focused on ensuring competitiveness above the welfare of the largely female workforce.
